nexttext:
\noindent with $\Phi^{\mu\nu}_{\Delta\Gamma} = \eta_{\Delta\Gamma} g^{\nu\delta} \tilde{\nabla}_\gamma [e^\Lambda_\delta \tau^{\mu\gamma}_\Lambda]$, $\partial \mathcal{M} = \mathcal{T}$, $\mu = \tilde{\nabla}_\mu \kappa^\mu$, and $\tilde{\nabla}_\gamma$ is the torsionless covariant derivative. (\ref{eq:motion}) can be shown to reduce to GR under weak field conditions, for negligible torsion, $d=3$ and introducing the known constants of GR (Newton's and cosmological constant) \cite{Mandrin_NDA}, in accord to available experimental data. Here, we briefly outline how this can be proven.


We first introduce the quantity

\noindent with $\tau^{\alpha\beta\gamma} = \tau^{\alpha\gamma}_\Gamma \ \eta^{\Gamma\Delta} \ e_\Delta^\beta$, $\nabla_\gamma g_{\alpha\beta} = 0$ and $\rho^{\alpha\beta} = \nabla_\gamma\tau^{\alpha\beta\gamma}$.

\noindent Using the equation

\noindent Using the equation
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\delta\int_{\mathcal{M}}{\rm d}^{d+1}x\ \sqrt{-g}\ [\rho+\mu]=0," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><msub><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℳ</mi></msub><mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+5pt"><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+5pt"><msqrt><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>g</mi></mrow></msqrt></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mi>ρ</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

oindent where $\chi_{\mu
u} = ho_{\mu
u} - ho g_{\mu
u} / 2$ and $	heta^{\mu
u} =  rac{2}{\sqrt{-g}} \  rac{\delta (\sqrt{-g} \mu)}{\delta g_{\mu
u}}$. By performing an infinitesimal translation $x^\mu ightarrow x^\mu + \epsilon a^\mu(x^
u)$ and integrating $	heta_{\mu
u}$ over a region $\mathcal{M}$ with $	heta^\lambda_
u a^
u = 0$ on the boundary, one can show that $	heta^{\mu
u}$ and $\chi^{\mu
u}$ are divergence-free. Furthermore, considering contributions to $\chi_{\mu
u}$ no higher than quadratic in the dimension of derivatives of $g_{\mu
u}$, one can show that $\chi_{\mu
u}$ only may have terms $\sim G_{\mu
u}$ and $\sim g_{\mu
u}$, where $G_{\mu
u}$ is the Einstein tensor and the second contribution has the form of the cosmological constant term. This concludes the outline of the proof.

By analogy to GR, the quantity $\mu$ can be interpreted as the ''matter term'' (corresponding to $T^\mu_\mu$). Any symmetries imposed to the parameterisation contribute some part $\mu_{m psc}$ to $\mu$, and $\mu_{m psc}$ satisfies these symmetries. This is similar to the symmetry properties of the QFT Lagrangian of a free matter field on a background space and suggests us to define dual fields $\psi_l(x^k)$ so that $\mu_{m psc} \sim \sum_l |\psi_l|^2$.




\section{Quantum formalism}
\label{sec:quantum}

Experimental evidence of quantum behaviour involves detectors which are sensitive to a narrow selection out of $n_D$ possible quantum processes $P1 \ldots Pn_D$. Each detector represents a macroscopic system of many quanta. In order to predict the occurrence of e.g. $P1$, we need to compute the probability of detecting $P1$ rather than $P2 \ldots Pn_D$. For any channel $Pk$, $k=1\ldots n_D$, we determine the macroscopic state with the largest number $\Omega_{Pk}$ of microstates under the observational data constraint $\mu_{Pk}$ by evaluating $\delta S_c ig|_{\mu=\mu_{m psc}+\mu_{Pk}} = 0$. Then, the probability for $P1$ is

\section{Quantum formalism}
\label{sec:quantum}

Experimental evidence of quantum behaviour involves detectors which are sensitive to a narrow selection out of $n_D$ possible quantum processes $P1 \ldots Pn_D$. Each detector represents a macroscopic system of many quanta. In order to predict the occurrence of e.g. $P1$, we need to compute the probability of detecting $P1$ rather than $P2 \ldots Pn_D$. For any channel $Pk$, $k=1\ldots n_D$, we determine the macroscopic state with the largest number $\Omega_{Pk}$ of microstates under the observational data constraint $\mu_{Pk}$ by evaluating $\delta S_c ig|_{\mu=\mu_{m psc}+\mu_{Pk}} = 0$. (V,T)}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>Z</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>V</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>T</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>≈</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∏</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>γ</mi></mrow></munder><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>e</mi><mi>γ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi></msubsup></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="7.5pt" stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∏</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Λ</mi></mrow></munder><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Λ</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="7.5pt" stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>c</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>V</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>T</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\noindent Ignoring the connection part, one recovers the path integral formulation of torsionless gravity. This formulation applies to a slowly varying mean curvature, but not in the case of locally unbounded gradients of the curvature and therefore of $s$.

In the special case of the flat ($d+1$)-parameter space approximation, the approximation of local thermal equilibrium applies trivially and yields an expression of the form of the integral path representation of quantum field theory \cite{Mandrin_NDA} (for $\mu = \mu_{\rm psc}$):
prevtext: \noindent where $\omega_{\mu\Delta\Lambda}$ is the connection one-form. Integrating $Z(V, T)$ over a large volume yields an expression of the form ($\tilde{e}^\Gamma_\gamma$, $\tilde{\omega}_{\mu\Delta\Lambda}$ equal $e^\Gamma_\gamma$, $\omega_{\mu\Delta\Lambda}$ times scaling factors)

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E9.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="Z_{\rm tot}=\int[\prod_{\Gamma,\gamma}\mathcal{D}\tilde{e}^{\Gamma}_{\gamma}]%
\ [\prod_{\mu,\Delta\leq\Lambda}\mathcal{D}\tilde{\omega}_{\mu\Delta\Lambda}]%
\ {\rm e}^{{\rm i}S_{c}(V,T)}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>Z</mi><mi>tot</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∏</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>γ</mi></mrow></munder><mrow><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒟</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mover accent="true"><mi>e</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mi>γ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi></msubsup></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="7.5pt" stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∏</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Λ</mi></mrow></munder><mrow><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒟</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>ω</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Λ</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="7.5pt" stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>c</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>V</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>T</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
\noindent Ignoring the connection part, one recovers the path integral formulation of torsionless gravity. This formulation applies to a slowly varying mean curvature, but not in the case of locally unbounded gradients of the curvature and therefore of $s$.

In the special case of the flat ($d+1$)-parameter space approximation, the approximation of local thermal equilibrium applies trivially and yields an expression of the form of the integral path representation of quantum field theory \cite{Mandrin_NDA} (for $\mu = \mu_{\rm psc}$):

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E10.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="Z(V_{\rm tot})\approx\lim_{K\rightarrow\infty}\prod_{k=1}^{K}Z(V_{k},T_{k})=%
\int[\prod_{l}\mathcal{D}\psi_{l}]\ \exp({\rm i}\int_{V_{\rm tot}}{\rm d}^{d+1%
}x\ \mu_{\rm psc})." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>Z</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>tot</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>≈</mo><mrow><munder><mo movablelimits="false">lim</mo><mrow><mi>K</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow></munder><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∏</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>K</mi></munderover><mrow><mi>Z</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>k</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mi>k</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∏</mo><mi>l</mi></munder><mrow><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒟</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ψ</mi><mi>l</mi></msub></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="7.5pt" stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>exp</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><msub><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>tot</mi></msub></msub><mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+5pt"><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>psc</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>
